original_title: Sri Lanka Treasury bill auction yields plunge after CB dollar purchases
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Treasury bill yields plunged across maturities, dealers said after a surrender rule was lifted on the exchange rate, leading to an appreciation rupee.
The 3-month yield fell to 27.94 percent from 28.75 a week earlier,  according to bid results sent to dealers. The cut-off was believed to be just above the weighted average.
Amid a strike by central bank staff the usual press release was not sent at the usual time.
All 50 billion rupees of the 30-month maturity offered was sold. After the auction the 3-momnth was quoted at 26.27 percent.
The 6-month bill was sold at 27.34 percent, down from 27.77 percent. All 35 billion offered was sold.
The 12-month bill was sold at 25.92 percent, down from 26.43 percent last week. All 35 billion offered was sold.
Sri Lanka’s central bank lifted a surrender rule on the US dollar helping appreciate the rupee and generate rupee liquidity in banks.
But some of the money can also end up in back in forex markets through Treasury bill sales.
The central bank has bought about 500 million US dollar from dollar holders and banks since the surrender rule was lifted. (Colombo/Mar15/2023)
